channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: 19 States Sue to Block White House Plan to End Gender-Related Care for Minors
item.description: The coalition of states seeks to stop a Trump administration effort to cut off federal funding to hospitals that provide such care.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquín and Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Letitia James, left, attorney general of New York, at a conference in May with attorneys general from other states including, from left, Rob Bonta of California, Kwame Raoul of Illinois, Keith Ellison of Minnesota and Matt Platkin of New Jersey.

item.title: Judge Blocks Conditions Imposed on States Seeking FEMA Grants
item.description: The Trump administration had sought to require states to account for population losses tied to deportations in order to receive emergency preparedness grants.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:description: Residents searched through debris after a tornado passed through London, Ky., in May. Kentucky is one of 11 states that sued over federal efforts to withhold FEMA grants over population counts.

item.title: Redacted Material in Some Epstein Files Is Easily Recovered
item.description: The ease of recovering information that was not properly redacted digitally suggests that at least some of the documents released by the Justice Department were hastily censored.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar
item.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera Pichardo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The executors of Jeffrey Epstein’s estate faced a civil suit filed in the Virgin Islands in 2021. Documents from the suit released late Monday included some that were not properly redacted digitally. Above, the court in 2020.

item.title: U.S. Is Adding to Its Military Buildup in the Caribbean
item.description: Over the past week, C-17 heavy-lift cargo planes, which usually transport troops and equipment, flew to Puerto Rico at least 16 times, according to flight tracking data reviewed by The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Ground crews unloaded cargo last week from an Air Force C-17 Globemaster III aircraft, top, parked next to a U.S. Air Force HC-130 aircraft, at the Roosevelt Roads naval base in Ceiba, Puerto Rico.

item.title: Suspect in Brown University Shooting Worked in Portugal After Leaving University
item.description: One friend said Claudio Neves Valente appeared to live a detached life, upset that “he couldn’t be the genius he thought he should be.”
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis and Azam Ahmed
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial was set up outside the Van Wickle Gates at Brown University.

item.title: National Guard Troops to Arrive in New Orleans
item.description: The troops will join an existing wave of Border Patrol agents, months after Gov. Jeff Landry first suggested that the National Guard could help tamp down on crime in Louisiana.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kathleen Flynn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the National Guard will join Border Patrol agents who have already been in New Orleans since early December as part of a federal crackdown on undocumented immigration.

item.title: Trooper Killed at Motor Vehicle Office in Delaware
item.description: Deputies responded to a report of an active shooter at the Division of Motor Vehicles office in Wilmington, Del., the authorities said. The gunman has also died, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Local news reports showed a heavy police presence on Tuesday after a shooting at a Division of Motor Vehicles office in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: Pennsylvania Nursing Home Explosion Kills 2
item.description: A resident and an employee were killed after two explosions at the Bristol Health and Rehab Center resulted in a large fire and partial collapse of the building, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel, Rylee Kirk, Pooja Salhotra, Mark Bonamo and Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: A gas explosion at a nursing home in Bristol, Pa., drew a large emergency response on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Supreme Court Refuses to Allow Trump to Deploy National Guard in Chicago
item.description: President Trump ordered state-based troops to Portland, Ore.; Los Angeles; Washington; and Chicago over the objections of state and local officials.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The president’s efforts to use troops for domestic policing have prompted legal challenges accusing the Trump administration of exceeding its authority.

item.title: Pro-Trump Influencers Stay Conspicuously Quiet About Epstein Files
item.description: Their silence contrasted with the uproar made over the weekend when the Justice Department’s first release focused on former President Bill Clinton.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump was mentioned multiple times in the documents the Justice Department released about Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Oklahoma Instructor Mel Curth Who Failed Student Samantha Fulnecky’s Gender Essay Is Fired
item.description: The instructor, a graduate student at the University of Oklahoma, gave a zero to a student who wrote an essay arguing in favor of traditional gender definitions based on biblical teachings.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: The University of Oklahoma campus in Norman, Okla.

item.title: Document Hinted at Further Prosecutions in Epstein Investigation
item.description: The 2020 email laid out the criminal charges and investigative steps that prosecutors were mulling at the time.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich, Matthew Goldstein and Benjamin Weiser
item.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein in a photo released by the Justice Department. After Mr. Epstein’s death in jail in 2019, federal prosecutors mulled bringing criminal charges against his associates.

item.title: New Epstein Papers Appear to Show Former Prince Andrew Seeking ‘Girls’
item.description: In emails sent to Ghislaine Maxwell, a man at the British royal family’s summer residence in Scotland asks Ms. Maxwell for “new inappropriate friends,” then inquires about “girls” ahead of a trip to Peru.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Debra Kamin
item.media:description: Balmoral Castle, the favored summer residence of the British royal family, in Aberdeenshire, Scotland, in 2023.

item.title: Stephen Miller Cites Children of Immigrants as a Problem
item.description: As it seeks to end birthright citizenship, the Trump administration is arguing that immigrants bring problems that extend for generations. The data shows otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: Stephen Miller is stressing an argument that immigrants bring problems to the United States that extend through generations.

item.title: In Epstein Files, Administration Officials Point to Clinton, and Away From Trump
item.description: The Justice Department initially removed, then restored, a photograph that included an image of President Trump, and issued a statement calling mentions of him “untrue and sensationalist claims.”
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Image released by the Justice Department
item.media:description: The Justice Department released a number of photographs and documents related to Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: The Confederacy Goes on Trial, Along With Schools Named Jackson and Lee
item.description: In an unusual trial, the N.A.A.C.P. has sought to show a school board’s “racist intent” by proving that the names of Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson can’t be separated from white supremacy.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:credit: Eze Amos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stonewall Jackson High School was renamed Mountain View High School in 2020. The change was reversed by the Shenandoah County School Board in 2024.

item.title: Federal Agents Tried to Contact ‘Co-Conspirators’ in Epstein Case, Emails Show
item.description: The list of co-conspirators included Leslie Wexner, the retail magnate behind The Limited and Victoria’s Secret stores.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

item.title: Trump Administration Delays Tariffs on Chinese Semiconductors
item.description: An investigation ruled that China’s inroads into the chip industry had hurt the United States. The administration delayed tariffs until 2027 amid a fragile truce between the countries.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: Office of the United States Trade Representative
item.media:description: The Trump administration has tried to maintain a truce with China because of tensions regarding tariffs.

item.title: Ben Sasse, Former Nebraska Senator, Shares Terminal Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis
item.description: Mr. Sasse, a former senator from Nebraska, announced that he had received a diagnosis last week for Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan, Charles Homans and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ben Sasse in 2022, when he was a U.S. senator from Nebraska.

item.title: Federal Prosecutor Was Surprised by Trump’s Flights on Epstein’s Jet
item.description: A 2020 email noted that Donald Trump was listed as a passenger on Jeffrey Epstein’s jet at least eight times from 1993 to 1996.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich

item.title: Rotating Cast of Wall Street Figures Were Listed as Executors of Epstein’s Will
item.description: Copies of Jeffrey Epstein’s last will and testament show that the convicted sex offender and disgraced financier provide a real-time glimpse of the power players who were part of his life.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich and Debra Kamin
item.media:description: Jimmy Cayne, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, was named as one of the executors in versions of Jeffrey Epstein’s will.

item.title: How Did DOGE Disrupt So Much While Saving So Little?
item.description: The group’s biggest claims were largely incorrect, a New York Times analysis found. And its many smaller cuts added up to few savings.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger, David A. Fahrenthold, Alicia Parlapiano and Margot Sanger-Katz

item.title: DOJ Releases Another Batch of Epstein Files: Key Takeaways
item.description: The new documents — nearly 30,000 in all — contain hundreds of references to President Trump and include different versions of Jeffrey Epstein’s will.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin, Katie Benner, Benjamin Weiser and Julie Tate

item.title: New Jersey Honors Bomb-Sniffing Dogs Who Kept an Election Safe
item.description: For their heroics after a wave of bomb threats in New Jersey on Election Day, more than two dozen dogs were presented with an award from the state attorney general.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Amir Hamja
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

item.title: This Texas Family Was Part of the Biggest U.S. Measles Outbreak in a Generation
item.description: The measles outbreak in the United States is now in its 11th month, with almost 2,000 cases. The Timmons family were some of the first people to get sick.
item.dc:creator: Eli Saslow
item.media:description: Five members of the Timmons family were hospitalized for their symptoms from measles.
